Message.Title: ORCL buys Xsigo
Message.Msg: Is CSCO dead yet? http://blogs.barrons.com/techtraderdaily/2012/07/30/ctxs-bernstein-dismisses-oracle-vmware-threats/?mod=yahoobarrons However, Moerdler believes that while Nicira and Xsigo products may give networking vendors such as Cisco Systems (CSCO) added competition, it won’t be a direct threat to Citrix because Citrix focuses on application virtualization, rather than affecting the underlying network infrastructure: We believe that this acquisition coupled with VMware’s acquisition of Nicera, (another software-defined networking solution provider) is making investors worried that Citrix’s Netscaler sales will be impacted. Xsigo may look more like Citrix’s Netscaler, given that it is combination of hardware and software, but itcompetes in a different part of the market. Netscaler plays in the higher layers of the networking stack, while Xsigo and Nicera focus on the lower layers. Network architectures are built out of layers with the higher the layer, the more abstract the data: going from physical signals (layer 1) to application communication (layer 7) (see Exhibit 1).VMware’s Nicera operates at layers 2 and 3, which are parts of the media layer and Xsigo operates at layers 1 thru 3. Layers 1 through 3 have historically been the purview of network vendors such as Cisco and Juniper. On the other hand, Citrix’s NetScaler operates higher up at the host layers (Level 4 through 7).

Topic.Title: White House gives cool welcome to bill restricting online ammo sales

Message.Msg: The chairman of the powerful House Intelligence Committee told Fox News that security leaks out of the Obama administration have not stopped despite an internal probe, and that President Obama has not done enough to turn off the spigot. Without providing specifics about the new leaks, Rep. Mike Rogers, R-Mich., said the damaging release of sensitive information continues. “We’ve seen more leaks, absolutely,” Rogers told Fox News in an interview Monday. “This is an opportunity for the president to be bold, to take a stand, to step up and say, ‘My administration will cooperate fully and that my staff ... should not and will not participate in coordinated or uncoordinated leaking of classified information for any reason. It's a crime.'" Rogers, following up on criticisms of the leaks made last week by Dianne Feinstein, the Democratic chair of the Senate Intelligence Committee, Rogers agreed that human intelligence assets had been comprised. “We know that sources have self selected out of cooperation around the world,” Rogers explained. “We know that operations have had to change. We know that operations have had to shut down.” Based on the work by his committee investigators, the congressman joined other Republicans by claiming that the classified information came from a small group of people who have access to the White House. “It is very clear that somebody who had access to the White House situation room, had very senior covert action classified material was responsible for some of these leaks," he said. "That is not a big group of people." On the level of cooperation from the White House, Rogers suggested it was lacking.
